stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on designing the overworld, focusing on level flow, creating thematic barriers like giant fruit, and planning non-linear progression. A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to a complex technical deep-dive, implementing a dynamic, localized fog effect for the ghost ship entrance in Overworld Part 3.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has systematically replaced most of the original Mario 64 engine, including rendering, animation (using quaternions), camera, collision, and the skybox system, with his own custom code.
development_findings.quote: Well, what you probably don't realize is that like almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

development_findings.summary: The development strategy is to work on multiple areas concurrently in a rough state rather than perfecting one area at a time, preventing wasted work when later areas necessitate changes to earlier ones.
development_findings.quote: When we work on the other areas we will likely have to adjust this one again. So if we do that we waste a shit ton of time.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle for the overworld is non-linear progression, where players will need to complete later objectives (e.g., activating a lighthouse) to unlock access to earlier levels (e.g., a ghost ship).
development_findings.quote: You do something later in the game to unlock something early in the game, that's cool as fuck.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is replacing standard barriers like invisible walls with more diegetic obstacles, such as a giant banana or destroyed castles, to fit the Yoshi's Island theme.

A major technical challenge was implementing localized fog, which Kaze solved by creating a C-code driven system that calculates fog density based on camera angle and distance to the target, combined with static fog meshes.
Kaze is in the process of replacing the N64's underlying operating system (libultra) with his own, aiming to improve performance and potentially create a legally distinct game.
development_findings.quote: I'm actually working on reworking the operating system right now as well...I'm going to remove all of lip ultra because lip ultra is dog shit unoptimized piece of shit code.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that even disliked parts of a game can be essential for creating contrast and making the overall design functional.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes the part that people least like about the game are also the parts that are most necessary to make the game's design work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that for most applications, the choice of programming language is less important than the programmer's skill, unless performance is a critical factor.
context_findings.quote: I think only really bad programmers care about which programming language they use for most applications.

context_findings.summary: Kaze distinguishes between his paid commission work, like 'Drug Boss Mario', and 'Return to Yoshi's Island', which is purely a passion project.
context_findings.quote: There's a lot of money to be made in romhacking. But this one here is not any paid work at all. This is just me working because of passion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on how his cognitive abilities have changed over time, feeling he has become more specialized in game design-related thinking and less adept at other types of problem-solving, like formal mathematics.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes I feel like I'm getting older and my brain doesn't work like it used to anymore. And then I also think that maybe my neurons just got more optimized and less variable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with technical issues in third-party software like NVIDIA Broadcast and OBS, which crashed mid-stream.
context_findings.quote: Why are there so many dogshit programmers working on all this software?

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for the final visual rework and polish of the overworld areas that Kaze is currently blocking out.
biobak.quote: I'd like to see the Biobak rework of the overworld.

biobak.summary: Kaze's development process is dependent on Biobak's future work; features like long-distance views between overworld sections are planned for after Biobak's 'final rework'.

zeina.summary: Zeina created a high-resolution render of the ghost ship, which Kaze used as a visual reference during the stream.
zeina.quote: Did you just make the ship for this render? Interesting.

zeina.summary: Zeina provided real-time feedback and ideas for the fog effect, prompting a discussion about their creative communication and collaborative dynamic.
zeina.quote: Maybe sometimes you have good ideas, and you just don't communicate them correctly. Which would be tragic. You should work on that.

key_stories.title: The Dynamic Fog Problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create a localized fog effect for a ghost ship, a significant technical challenge. He struggled through brainstorming, coding bugs, and mathematical formulas, finally arriving at a multi-layered solution that combines dynamic code-driven fog with visual tricks to create the desired atmospheric barrier.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a convincing, localized fog effect around the Ghost Ship on N64 hardware was a major technical and design hurdle. The fog needed to be dynamic based on player position and view angle without using a global fog that would affect the entire area.
key_stories.process: Kaze first dismissed performance-heavy methods like stacked transparent planes. He then began coding a solution in C, battling with his tool's limitations, inverted logic for fog values, and non-linear falloff curves. After significant debugging and iterating on the math, he combined his dynamic fog with other visual tricks to achieve the final result.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a hybrid solution combining multiple techniques: dynamic, code-driven fog whose intensity is calculated in real-time, plus static 'fake fog' meshes to enhance the effect. This created the desired atmospheric and gameplay barrier.
key_stories.key_quote: Our entire issue, 100% of our issue is that we want the fork to be around the ship. That's entirely the problem.

key_stories.title: The Custom Engine
key_stories.summary: When asked about porting the game, Kaze revealed the extent to which he has replaced the original Mario 64 engine with his own custom code. He detailed how RTYI is now effectively running on his own engine, born out of a need for greater control and performance, with ambitions to eventually make it a legally distinct product.
key_stories.challenge: The original Super Mario 64 engine has significant limitations for creating a modern, complex game. To realize his vision for RTYI, Kaze needed more power and flexibility than the vanilla engine could offer.
key_stories.process: Over the course of his projects, Kaze has systematically reverse-engineered and replaced core components of the SM64 engine. This includes rendering, animation, camera, collision, physics steps, and even basic movement. He is currently working on replacing the base operating system itself.
key_stories.outcome: The project now runs on a highly customized engine. Kaze has a clear roadmap of the final pieces (sound engine, OS, remaining Mario actions) he would need to replace to create a completely standalone, potentially sellable game, free of Nintendo's original code.
key_stories.key_quote: Well, what you probably don't realize is that like almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.
